update.description: `WorkerPool` manages a bunch of worker threads. Each thread gets a job from a queue in the pool and processes it in parallel. "Work" is a function that does something useful and returns in a finite amount of time.
update.title: Thread/Worker pool

update.description: `WorkerPool` manages a bunch of worker threads. Each thread gets a job from a queue in the pool and processes it in parallel. "Work" is a function that does something useful and returns in a finite amount of time.
update.title: Thread/Worker pool

content.raw: I think I'm wrong about this check, and should remove it. `WorkerPool` doesn't have copy or move constructors, so it can't be copied or moved. The implicit copy constructor is deleted because `std::unique_ptr` copy constructor is deleted, and the implicit move constructor is deleted because there is a declared destructor. I don't see a path to making `dataPtr` null.
content.html: I think I'm wrong about this check, and should remove it. WorkerPool doesn't have copy or move constructors, so it can't be copied or moved. The implicit copy constructor is deleted because std::unique_ptr copy constructor is deleted, and the implicit move constructor is deleted because there is a declared destructor. I don't see a path to making dataPtr null.

content.raw: Right. This remark applies if a thread has a reference to a `WorkerPool`, calls`WaitForResults()` with no arguments, and while it's waiting another thread destructs the `WorkerPool`. In that case this method will stop blocking the first thread and return false.
content.html: Right. This remark applies if a thread has a reference to a WorkerPool, callsWaitForResults() with no arguments, and while it's waiting another thread destructs the WorkerPool. In that case this method will stop blocking the first thread and return false.

content.raw: I only have a few clarification comments and a tiny style nitpick, but this works for me.
content.html: I only have a few clarification comments and a tiny style nitpick, but this works for me.

content.raw: Just a clarification, if the `WorkerPool` is destructed, this function can't be used anymore, right?
content.html: Just a clarification, if the WorkerPool is destructed, this function can't be used anymore, right?

content.raw: Interesting, is this something we should worry about with every class? Should dataPtr be checked on other functions as well, or would this only affect the destructor?
content.html: Interesting, is this something we should worry about with every class? Should dataPtr be checked on other functions as well, or would this only affect the destructor?

content.raw: Style nitpick: functions come before variables
